results.title: Dax's Case
results.brief_description: This documentary raised vital questions about a patient’s right to choose whether to live or die, and about the role of the medical and legal profession. In 1973 Dax Cowart, a former air force pilot, was the victim of an explosion which left him blind, disfigured and suffering excruciating pain from severe burns. Despite persistent pleas to be allowed to die, Dax was kept alive. Now, leading a full life, he still maintains that he should have been allowed to die.

results.title: Dax
results.creator_credit: Antony Barrier and Mary Glasgow Audio-Visual
results.brief_description: This film tells the story of two teenage girls who arrive for a few days holiday at Dax, a thermal station in the Pyrenees Department of Lands. The narration and conversation are in simple, easy to understand French.

results.title: Dawn of the solar age
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: A survey of current methods of, and projects for, harnessing solar energy is presented in an attempt to answer the question - when oil supplies end, can the world’s industries be run by solar energy?

results.title: Dawn of the dead (Uncut version) [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Richard Rubinstein, Laurel Group Productions and George A. Romero
results.brief_description: In this sequel to George Romero’s “Night of the living dead”, the US is engulfed and decimated by a zombie population growing at an inexplicable and alarming rate. Two Philadelphia police S.W.A.T. officers, a helicopter pilot and his TV reporter girlfriend escape the city and take refuge in an abandoned suburban shopping mall. Their attempts to isolate themselves from the marauding army of the undead are thwarted after a band of looters leave a door open allowing the zombies free access to the mall. Romero capitalises on the shopping mall location to present an apocalyptic allegory for a rampant consumer culture driven to eat itself by its own insatiable appetite. Cast includes David Emge, Ken Foree, Scott H. Reininger. Music by Dario Argento.

results.title: Dawn of the clone age
results.creator_credit: Deborah Cadbury and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Dolly the sheep’s birth on 23 February 1997 became world news for Dolly was to be the first successful cloning of a sheep. The next step surely would be the cloning of humans! This interesting and informative documentary tells the story behind this most amazing feat in biological research and of the team who were responsible in bringing it about. The program also discusses the bioethics and concerns raised by many in the scientific and academic world about cloning and genetic engineering, particularly in the cloned embryo area. Includes interviews with some of “Dolly’s” creators, namely Dr Ian Wilmut, Dr Henry Griffin, Dr John Clark and Dr Keith Campbell (all from the Roslin Institute) and uses microphotography and computer animation to illustrate the intricacies involved in the research and techniques of genetic engineering and embryology. Poses the question about the future and the “brave new world” of cloning - will it be used in the treatment of diseases such as cystic fibrosis or haemophilia or, as feared by many, in the cloning of super humans? Narrated by Hugh Quarshie.

results.title: Dawn of a new era: America enters the 20th century
results.creator_credit: SL Film Productions and Gerald A Schiller
results.brief_description: Looks at the United States at the turn of the century, from McKinley’s inauguration to the early days of Theodore Roosevelt’s presidency. It was the world’s largest industrial nation and employed on million children aged between ten and fifteen years earning $3.50 per week. Also shows New York at that time. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Dawn
results.creator_credit: Alice Markowitz, David Espar, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, WGBH (Boston) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Nuclear age”.
This program examines the background of the decision to drop the atomic bomb on Hiroshima on August 6, 1945. It was a decision which shocked and profoundly changed the world, killing and mutilating thousands. There were mixed reactions of pride and horror. “We had calculated beforehand how much destruction there would be. But seeing it on films was much more terrible.” was one reaction of the time. The pilot was given a hero’s welcome, a medal and a celebration party.

results.title: Dawn
results.creator_credit: Joy Cavill, Aquataurus Film Productions and Ken Hannam
results.brief_description: Story of Australian swimmer Dawn Fraser. Dramatised biographical account of her life and times, and her acclaim as the first female athlete to win gold medals in three successive Olympic Games.

results.title: Davy Jones' locker
results.brief_description: From the animated series “Willie Whopper’s Adventures”, the story of Willie Whopper, a little boy with a big imagination. Willie tangles with denizens of the deep, including a vast and menacing Poseidon figure and a drunken pirate (Davy Jones), who swills hooch while slamming his peg-leg stump on the deck of his room. Lots of sea-creature sight gags, too.
